<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">Under hydrothermal conditions, using a triazole derivative ligand 3-carboxylic acid-4H-1,2,4-triazole (HL), lead(II) oxide and NH<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>NCS, a novel two-dimensional (2D) lead(II) framework {[Pb(L)(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">1,1</ce:inf>-NCS)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) can be isolated. For <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> NCS<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anions adopt novel <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">1,1</ce:inf>-(N)CS bridges, which are further extended by tetra-dentate coordinated L ligands to form a 2D corrugated layered structure. Solid-state luminescent spectrum of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows that the excited peak at 375<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm while the low-energy emission peak at 607<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Under hydrothermal conditions, using a triazole derivative ligand 3-carboxylic acid-4H-1,2,4-triazole (HL), lead(II) oxide and NH4NCS, a novel two-dimensional (2D) lead(II) framework {[Pb(L)(μ 1,1-NCS)(H2O)]} n  (1) can be isolated. For 1 NCS- anions adopt novel μ 1,1-(N)CS bridges, which are further extended by tetra-dentate coordinated L ligands to form a 2D corrugated layered structure. Solid-state luminescent spectrum of 1 shows that the excited peak at 375nm while the low-energy emission peak at 607nm.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">During the last two decades metal–organic coordination polymers have aroused great interest for chemists due to their extremely versatile coordination motifs and potential applications in many areas such as light-emitting diodes (LEDs), catalytic, magnetic and so on . Especially the lead(II) frameworks also have attracted great interest based on below points: (1) large ion radius, flexible variable coordination number from 2 to 10 and diverse coordination geometries for Pb<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ions make there is great potential in the construction of functional materials; (2) The intrinsic feature of Pb<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>, the presence of a 6S<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> outer electron, make Pb<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> frameworks have unique applications in coordination chemistry, photo-physics and photo-chemistry; (3) Inorganic–organic hybrid materials containing infinite Pb–O–Pb linkage also have aroused great interest .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

During the last two decades metal-organic coordination polymers have aroused great interest for chemists due to their extremely versatile coordination motifs and potential applications in many areas such as light-emitting diodes (LEDs), catalytic, magnetic and so on . Especially the lead(II) frameworks also have attracted great interest based on below points: (1) large ion radius, flexible variable coordination number from 2 to 10 and diverse coordination geometries for PbII ions make there is great potential in the construction of functional materials; (2) The intrinsic feature of PbII, the presence of a 6S2 outer electron, make PbII frameworks have unique applications in coordination chemistry, photo-physics and photo-chemistry; (3) Inorganic-organic hybrid materials containing infinite Pb-O-Pb linkage also have aroused great interest .

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Pseudo-halide NCS<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ligand is a favorable building block in the construction of novel metal–organic frameworks because it can adopt versatile coordination modes such as terminal N-, S-, or <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">1,3</ce:inf>-, <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">1,1</ce:inf>-bridging modes. Of all the coordination modes, <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">1,1</ce:inf>-(N)CS bridging way is scarcely reported and is also particular interest due to their important applications in magnetic systems, crystal engineering and so on . On the other hand, 1,2,4-triazole and its derivates are also good building blocks for constructing novel functional materials because they combine the coordination modes of pyrazole and imidazole . In particular, some Zn(II), Cd(II) and Ag(I) complexes with these ligands have been isolated exhibiting that they are good candidates for photo-luminescent materials . Recently a novel 3D porous Cd(II) MOF built with 4-pyridine-3-1,2,4-triazole has been isolated by us, its photo-luminescent properties can be tuned by the number of guest molecules . However, to date, quite few luminescent lead(II) frameworks with 1,2,4-triazole and its derivatives are reported. There is still great potential in exploring this area.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Pseudo-halide NCS- ligand is a favorable building block in the construction of novel metal-organic frameworks because it can adopt versatile coordination modes such as terminal N-, S-, or μ 1,3-, μ 1,1-bridging modes. Of all the coordination modes, μ 1,1-(N)CS bridging way is scarcely reported and is also particular interest due to their important applications in magnetic systems, crystal engineering and so on . On the other hand, 1,2,4-triazole and its derivates are also good building blocks for constructing novel functional materials because they combine the coordination modes of pyrazole and imidazole . In particular, some Zn(II), Cd(II) and Ag(I) complexes with these ligands have been isolated exhibiting that they are good candidates for photo-luminescent materials . Recently a novel 3D porous Cd(II) MOF built with 4-pyridine-3-1,2,4-triazole has been isolated by us, its photo-luminescent properties can be tuned by the number of guest molecules . However, to date, quite few luminescent lead(II) frameworks with 1,2,4-triazole and its derivatives are reported. There is still great potential in exploring this area.

elements.content:

elements.clean_text:
Experimental section

General remarks

Deionized water was used as solvent in this work. The ligand HL was prepared by the method described in the literature . Other reagents were purchased commercially and used without further purification. C, H and N microanalyses were carried out with a Perkin-Elmer 240 elemental analyzer. FT-IR spectrum was recorded from KBr pellets in the range 4000-400cm-1 on a Bio-Rad FTS 135 spectrometezr. Fluorescence spectrum was taken on a Varian Cary Eclipse spectrometer.

elements.clean_text:
Preparation of compound 1 

A mixture of PbO (44.6mg, 0.2mmol), H2L (22.4mg, 0.2mmol), NH4NCS (15.2mg, 0.2mmol) and H2O (18mL) were placed in a 25mL Teflon-lined steel vessel and heated to 140°C for 5 days, then cooled to room temperature. The resulting colorless block-shaped crystals of 1 were washed several times by water and diethyl ether. The yield is 45% based on Pb. Elemental analysis (%) calcd for 1: C 12.19%, H 0.77%, N 14.21%; found: C 12.01%, H 0.81%, N 14.29%.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Crystal structure determination</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Diffraction intensities for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was collected on a computer-controlled Bruker SMART 1000 CCD diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo-Kα radiation with radiation wavelength 0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å by using the ω-φ scan technique. Lorentz polarization and absorption corrections were applied. The structure was solved by direct methods and refined with the full-matrix least-squares technique using the SHELXS-97 and SHELXL-97 programs . Anisotropic thermal parameters were assigned to all non-hydrogen atoms. The organic hydrogen atoms were generated geometrically. Analytical expressions of neutral-atom scattering factors were employed, and anomalous dispersion corrections were incorporated. The crystallographic data and details of refinements for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> are summarized in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl1"></ce:float-anchor>; selected bond lengths and angles are listed in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl2"></ce:float-anchor>. CCDC-692328 (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) contains the supplementary crystallographic data for this work. The data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via <ce:inter-ref xlink:href="http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif" xlink:type="simple">www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif</ce:inter-ref>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Crystal structure determination

Diffraction intensities for 1 was collected on a computer-controlled Bruker SMART 1000 CCD diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo-Kα radiation with radiation wavelength 0.71073Å by using the ω-φ scan technique. Lorentz polarization and absorption corrections were applied. The structure was solved by direct methods and refined with the full-matrix least-squares technique using the SHELXS-97 and SHELXL-97 programs . Anisotropic thermal parameters were assigned to all non-hydrogen atoms. The organic hydrogen atoms were generated geometrically. Analytical expressions of neutral-atom scattering factors were employed, and anomalous dispersion corrections were incorporated. The crystallographic data and details of refinements for 1 are summarized in  ; selected bond lengths and angles are listed in  . CCDC-692328 (1) contains the supplementary crystallographic data for this work. The data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">For <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> single crystal X-ray analysis shows that the asymmetrical structure unit of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> contains one crystallographic independent PbII ion (Pb1), one <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">1,1</ce:inf>-(N)CS bridges, one de-protonated L and one terminal coordinated water molecule (O3). As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig1"></ce:float-anchor>, Pb1 is in the hemi-directed geometry and seven-coordinated by one water molecule (O3), two bridged <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">1,1</ce:inf>-(N)CS nitrogen atoms (N4 and N4A), two carboxylate oxygen atoms (O1 and O2) and two triazole atoms (N1 and N2) forming a quite distorted pentagonal bipyramid geometry. The Pb(II) coordination geometry has close relationship with the 6s electrons. The stereo-chemical active 6s electrons of Pb usually produce hemi-directed coordination geometry, however, the difference between hemi-directed and holo-directed geometry around Pb(II) is ambiguous sometimes . With the extending of bonding limit, the potential ligands, which are a little far from Pb(II) center due to the repulsion of the 6s electrons, will be found and the hemi-directed coordination sphere will be completed to holo-directed. For <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> the hemi-directed geometries of Pb1 also can be extended by weak Pb···S interactions (Pb(1)–S(1), 3.292(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) into holo-directed geometries. The carboxylic acid group of HL is de-protonated, N2, N3, O1 and O2 of L are involved in the coordination of two central lead(II) ions (Pb1 and Pb1A) forming tetra-dentate coordination modes. The result is also different form previously reported bi-dentate chelate coordination modes . All the bond distances and angles are listed in the , all the Pb–O and Pb–N bond distances are below 2.8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, such bond distances are reasonable and can find a nearly ideal value assumed for oxidation state II on the Pb<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ions. The five-membered triazole ring is almost coplanar with mean deviation of 0.0014(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

For 1 single crystal X-ray analysis shows that the asymmetrical structure unit of 1 contains one crystallographic independent PbII ion (Pb1), one μ 1,1-(N)CS bridges, one de-protonated L and one terminal coordinated water molecule (O3). As shown in  , Pb1 is in the hemi-directed geometry and seven-coordinated by one water molecule (O3), two bridged μ 1,1-(N)CS nitrogen atoms (N4 and N4A), two carboxylate oxygen atoms (O1 and O2) and two triazole atoms (N1 and N2) forming a quite distorted pentagonal bipyramid geometry. The Pb(II) coordination geometry has close relationship with the 6s electrons. The stereo-chemical active 6s electrons of Pb usually produce hemi-directed coordination geometry, however, the difference between hemi-directed and holo-directed geometry around Pb(II) is ambiguous sometimes . With the extending of bonding limit, the potential ligands, which are a little far from Pb(II) center due to the repulsion of the 6s electrons, will be found and the hemi-directed coordination sphere will be completed to holo-directed. For 1 the hemi-directed geometries of Pb1 also can be extended by weak Pb⋅⋅⋅S interactions (Pb(1)-S(1), 3.292(2)Å) into holo-directed geometries. The carboxylic acid group of HL is de-protonated, N2, N3, O1 and O2 of L are involved in the coordination of two central lead(II) ions (Pb1 and Pb1A) forming tetra-dentate coordination modes. The result is also different form previously reported bi-dentate chelate coordination modes . All the bond distances and angles are listed in the , all the Pb-O and Pb-N bond distances are below 2.8Å, such bond distances are reasonable and can find a nearly ideal value assumed for oxidation state II on the PbII ions. The five-membered triazole ring is almost coplanar with mean deviation of 0.0014(3)Å.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">As shown in , two <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">1,1</ce:inf>-NCS<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ligands act as bridging ligands to join neighboring lead(II) centers (Pb1 and Pb1A) forming novel Pb-(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">1,1</ce:inf>-NCS)-Pb bridges, which further extend <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> into a 2D corrugated layered structure. For Pb-(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">1,1</ce:inf>-NCS)-Pb bridges the separation of Pb1 and Pb1A is 4.307(5)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and the corresponding angle of Pb–N–Pb is 105.1°. Further these dimeric lead(II) building blocks are arranged in two different directions and are extended by bridging L ligands forming a 2D corrugated layer structure parallel to crystallographic ac plane (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor>). For <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> neighboring 2D layers stacking in ABAB… way. The interlayer Pb···Pb separations in the two neighboring layers are 7.645(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. Between these neighboring 2D layers coordinated water molecule (O3), carboxylate oxygen atom O2 generate strong O–H···O hydrogen bonds, further consolidating the overall framework structure (O3–H3B···O2, 2.849<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig3"></ce:float-anchor>). Though the lead(II) frameworks containing <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">1,3</ce:inf>-NCS bridging ligands have been reported, the framework structures containing <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">1,1</ce:inf>-NCS bridging ligands are still scarcely reported.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: As shown in , two μ 1,1-NCS- ligands act as bridging ligands to join neighboring lead(II) centers (Pb1 and Pb1A) forming novel Pb-(μ 1,1-NCS)-Pb bridges, which further extend 1 into a 2D corrugated layered structure. For Pb-(μ 1,1-NCS)-Pb bridges the separation of Pb1 and Pb1A is 4.307(5)Å and the corresponding angle of Pb-N-Pb is 105.1°. Further these dimeric lead(II) building blocks are arranged in two different directions and are extended by bridging L ligands forming a 2D corrugated layer structure parallel to crystallographic ac plane ( ). For 1 neighboring 2D layers stacking in ABAB… way. The interlayer Pb⋅⋅⋅Pb separations in the two neighboring layers are 7.645(1)Å. Between these neighboring 2D layers coordinated water molecule (O3), carboxylate oxygen atom O2 generate strong O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds, further consolidating the overall framework structure (O3-H3B⋅⋅⋅O2, 2.849Å) ( ). Though the lead(II) frameworks containing μ 1,3-NCS bridging ligands have been reported, the framework structures containing μ 1,1-NCS bridging ligands are still scarcely reported.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">FT-IR spectrum of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits the typical characteristic band centered at 1986<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> expected for 1,1-<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>-bridging thiocyanate ligands . A strong and broad absorption band centered at 3413<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, which can be ascribed to the presence of coordinated water molecules in the structure. The absence of the bands at ca. 1700<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> indicates that the carboxylic acid group is de-protonated. The triazole out of plane ring absorption can be observed at 644<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>
. The solid-state luminescent spectrum of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> also has been recorded at room temperature indicating a low-energy luminescence emission peak at 607<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm upon excitation at 375<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig4"></ce:float-anchor>). The low-energy emissions associated with large Stokes shifts can be observed for s<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>-metal complexes, which can be assigned to a metal-centered transition involving the s and p metal orbital as proposed by Vogler. Thus the emission band of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can be assigned to a metal-centered s–p transition.</ce:para>

A strong and broad absorption band centered at 3413cm-1, which can be ascribed to the presence of coordinated water molecules in the structure. The absence of the bands at ca. 1700cm-1 indicates that the carboxylic acid group is de-protonated. The triazole out of plane ring absorption can be observed at 644cm-1 . The solid-state luminescent spectrum of 1 also has been recorded at room temperature indicating a low-energy luminescence emission peak at 607nm upon excitation at 375nm ( ). The low-energy emissions associated with large Stokes shifts can be observed for s2-metal complexes, which can be assigned to a metal-centered transition involving the s and p metal orbital as proposed by Vogler. Thus the emission band of 1 can be assigned to a metal-centered s-p transition.

elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, under hydrothermal conditions, using a triazole derivative ligand 3-carboxylic acid-4H-1,2,4-triazole (HL), lead(II) oxide and NH4NCS, a novel two-dimensional (2D) lead(II) framework {[Pb(L)(μ 1,1-NCS)(H2O)]} n  (1) can be isolated. For 1 NCS- anions adopt novel μ 1,1-(N) bridges, which are further extended by tetra-dentate coordinated L ligands to form a 2D corrugated layered structure. NCS- also represents a novel μ 1,1-(N)CS bridging mode, which also reveals that thiocyanate co-ligand has great potential in the construction of novel inorganic-organic frameworks.

Results and discussion

For 1 single crystal X-ray analysis shows that the asymmetrical structure unit of 1 contains one crystallographic independent PbII ion (Pb1), one μ 1,1-(N)CS bridges, one de-protonated L and one terminal coordinated water molecule (O3). As shown in  , Pb1 is in the hemi-directed geometry and seven-coordinated by one water molecule (O3), two bridged μ 1,1-(N)CS nitrogen atoms (N4 and N4A), two carboxylate oxygen atoms (O1 and O2) and two triazole atoms (N1 and N2) forming a quite distorted pentagonal bipyramid geometry. The Pb(II) coordination geometry has close relationship with the 6s electrons. The stereo-chemical active 6s electrons of Pb usually produce hemi-directed coordination geometry, however, the difference between hemi-directed and holo-directed geometry around Pb(II) is ambiguous sometimes . With the extending of bonding limit, the potential ligands, which are a little far from Pb(II) center due to the repulsion of the 6s electrons, will be found and the hemi-directed coordination sphere will be completed to holo-directed. For 1 the hemi-directed geometries of Pb1 also can be extended by weak Pb⋅⋅⋅S interactions (Pb(1)-S(1), 3.292(2)Å) into holo-directed geometries. The carboxylic acid group of HL is de-protonated, N2, N3, O1 and O2 of L are involved in the coordination of two central lead(II) ions (Pb1 and Pb1A) forming tetra-dentate coordination modes. The result is also different form previously reported bi-dentate chelate coordination modes . All the bond distances and angles are listed in the , all the Pb-O and Pb-N bond distances are below 2.8Å, such bond distances are reasonable and can find a nearly ideal value assumed for oxidation state II on the PbII ions. The five-membered triazole ring is almost coplanar with mean deviation of 0.0014(3)Å.

FT-IR spectrum of compound 1 exhibits the typical characteristic band centered at 1986cm-1 expected for 1,1-μ-bridging thiocyanate ligands . A strong and broad absorption band centered at 3413cm-1, which can be ascribed to the presence of coordinated water molecules in the structure. The absence of the bands at ca. 1700cm-1 indicates that the carboxylic acid group is de-protonated. The triazole out of plane ring absorption can be observed at 644cm-1 . The solid-state luminescent spectrum of 1 also has been recorded at room temperature indicating a low-energy luminescence emission peak at 607nm upon excitation at 375nm ( ). The low-energy emissions associated with large Stokes shifts can be observed for s2-metal complexes, which can be assigned to a metal-centered transition involving the s and p metal orbital as proposed by Vogler. Thus the emission band of 1 can be assigned to a metal-centered s-p transition.
